title: Might as well remove stickers then
body:
Facilitate Civil Discussion- When you choose to participate in a discussion with the rest of the playerbase, always try to be respectful and receptive to another player's point of view. Also, be mindful of how you present your point of view. If a player feels strongly on a subject, don't get caught up trying to have the last word. Just state your side and exit the conversation gracefully rather than give them the opportunity to pick a fight.

So people that respond with {{sticker:slayer-jinx-unamused}} 
should have their comment removed. It doesn't facilitate civil discussion to respond with stickers, it's non-receptive to another player's point of view, and it isn't a mindful way to present a point of view. It seems like someone trying to get the last word. 

So, maybe don't enforce this stupid shit. Oh and this is the message I received because of this statement:
"Okay. Don't care about the opinions of hallway monitors. Go brown nose the principal."

What kind of pussy takes offense to that? And it's sad that the explanation I got was a bunch of bullshit that Ulanopo didn't even seem to buy. Like- yeah these people are pussies man just watch what you say so they I don't have to deal with them. Even sadder is this post might get taken down for a rhetorical question offending these people. 

"Did he call me a pussy because I take offense to nothing waaaahhh!!!"

replies.body:
You're right in feeling that stickers can be used and be seen as being dismissive. I feel that way too sometimes and have removed posts I felt crossed a line. They're open to far more interpretation, however, than something someone took the time to type out. One is a person picking from a relatively small palette of emoji. The other is a deliberate statement.

You might also have missed the following from your removal:

>I'd like to emphasize that this is not a warning; however, please take some time to familiarize yourself with the Boards Universal Rules, as well as the guidelines for any sub-board you intend to post in before you do so.

Your response in that thread was not helpful and the action was intended to remind you to use the Boards more respectfully. Your other post in that thread remains up, as it was a meaningful participation in the discussion.

> It's hard to pick out, but OP has a point. The most effective use of stickers is for BM.
>
> If stickers were removed, I think it would be a net benefit for civil discussion.

Removing the boards (and all other communication media, for that matter) would be a net benefit to civil discussion...by entirely removing the possibility of negative (or non-civil) discussion.
/sarcasm

Just like how stickers can (and yes, are) abused, the same can be said about how words on the boards can (and are) abused. Removing one medium just means someone will use others to get the same point across, good or bad.

> [{quoted}](name=Modi,realm=NA,application-id=6heBIhQc,discussion-id=hG3Xuhwj,comment-id=000200010000,timestamp=2019-08-19T17:35:04.954+0000)
>
> Removing the boards (and all other communication media, for that matter) would be a net benefit to civil discussion...by entirely removing the possibility of negative (or non-civil) discussion.

> 
> Just like how stickers can (and yes, are) abused, the same can be said about how words on the boards can (and are) abused. Removing one medium just means someone will use others to get the same point across, good or bad.

The stickers are especially prone to this, though.

If someone is trying to discuss an issue with a certain function of the game, I would argue that anybody replying with anything along the lines of "those are the rules deal with it" also fall under the "being receptive" condition of the rule. 

It doesn't seem receptive to dismiss people by stating the obvious statements of,  "that's how it is". 
So why aren't these "Hallway Monitors" having their comments removed? All they do is take from the integrity of Boards Discussions and turn a platform for civil discussion into a troll's den.

If a player has genuine concerns, other players should be discouraged from asserting the issue. But I don't see any of that. 
I don't see the right comments being removed. I see a certain "brown nosing" type of behavior being rewarded. 

Introducing an inherently circular argument means you are not being receptive to the other person's statement. But if I tell these people that their comments are irrelevant, I can have my comment removed. And this isn't the first time. I have literally had my comments removed for calling arguments "irrelevant" to the topic. 

The issue is Riot seems to ALLOW these people to take offense where none is literally present. And they're losing a loyal player base and making room for new players that will "play ball" with the bullshit.

Jeez, all this because **you do not/refuse to understood how Execution works**. What's worse is that literally everyone in that thread gave you a genuine response & you were the one being hostile against them.

Also, be mindful of how you present your point of view. If a player feels strongly on a subject, don't get caught up trying to have the last word. Just state your side and exit the conversation gracefully rather than give them the opportunity to pick a fight.

I consider it the right board since he is disagreeing with your cries of favoritism by saying you were ticking everyone off. He's on the correct board, please stop with this blatant double standard for yourself and against others.

"My comment was moderated so EVERYTHING should be moderated now."

Alternatively, you could follow the forum rules.

I don't think my comment should be moderated based on that explanation is my point. 
It would be like removing sticker comments because sticker comments could be argued to be the same
Knock it off, both of you.
Aren't you going to remove his comments under the same grounds you removed mine? Or am I detecting favoritism?
